presentation.runninghead: Climate mitigation from capture of atmospheric carbon
presentation.description: The benefits to humans of sequestering and storing atmospheric CO2

page.name: Climate Mitigation
page.title: Model coverage and general information
page.description:
Carbon sequestration by terrestrial ecosystems is the net removal of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere or the avoidance of CO2 emissions from terrestrial ecosystems into the atmosphere. The removal process includes CO2 uptake from the atmosphere by all chlorophyllous plants, through photosynthesis. This carbon (C) is stored as plant biomass (in the trunks, branches, leaves and roots of the plants) and organic matter in the soil (IPCC 2000). Terrestrial carbon sequestration depends on a series of factors including climatic conditions, vegetation structure and successional stage, and land use practices.

In ARIES, we distinguish between ecosystem sources of carbon sequestration capacity capable of removing CO2 from the atmosphere and storing carbon in vegetation and soils. We also map sinks, or areas that release stored carbon, largely via fire or deforestation. By subtracting the amount of stored carbon release from carbon sequestration in a region of interest, we are left with the carbon remaining available to offset anthropogenic emissions. Greenhouse gas emitters can be conceptualized as the beneficiaries of carbon sequestration and storage. Since greenhouse gas emitters benefit from the waste absorption capacity of the biosphere, carbon sequestration and storage can be divided among emitters. Existing and proposed systems to cap and assign property rights to atmospheric greenhouse gas emissions use this framework. In other words:

Carbon sequestration (source) – stored carbon release (sink) = carbon available to offset emissions (use)

By mapping levels of carbon sequestration, stored carbon release, and anthropogenic emissions in a common unit (tonnes C/ha.yr), we can fully describe regional carbon balances – the level of a region’s net release or uptake of atmospheric CO2. This will become increasingly important as local, state, and national governments continue to inventory greenhouse gas emissions and implement strategies to address climate change. Use of carbon sequestration is rival and occurs at the global scale through atmospheric mixing.
